text: SPEAKER: OK.

I'm not Debbie Kolb
as you noticed,

but I am presenting Debbie
Kolb's flash talk because she
couldn't be here today.

So I'm going to follow as
close as I can to the script

that she gave me, but just want
to say that this is her talk.

And this is a thought piece
that is based on an article

that she was recently invited to
publish in Negotiation Journal.

And what she was asked
to do was to speak

to the implications of the
Trump era for women negotiators.

And she used this metaphor,
Her Place at the Table,

because that was actually
the title of the first paper

that she ever wrote about
gender in negotiation.

I don't know if
anybody ever saw it?
Laura's nodding.

It was probably
about 30 years ago,
I think, that she wrote it.
And-- maybe 25 years ago.

And anyway, it was
her first foray

into this topic of
gender and negotiation.

She was a negotiation
scholar, and then she

was running the Harvard
project on negotiation.

And because she was
a woman, she was

asked to speak to issues of
gender about which she knew

very little, but she then spent
the rest of her career really

doing a lot of
writing, has written
several books in fact on that.

So, OK, she talks
about, in this article,

three implications of the
cult of the Trump era.

There are two downsides
and one upside,

so there are going to
be three implications.

The first one is that Her Place
at the Table is undermined.

And this is based
on research that

suggests that when women
are accepted as leaders,

they feel they have a
legitimate place at the table

and they negotiate
quite effectively.

So one implication
of the Trump era,

is that his misogynist
attitudes and efforts to curtail

women's rights,
give men permission

to exclude and diminish women,
as is evidenced in this quote

by a woman executive, whom
Debbie was interviewing shortly
after the election.

And she said, "I
was a bit delayed

dialing into a
conference call the day
after the 2016 election.

When I got on I heard
the others, all men,

say that they were glad that now
they were free to treat women
differently.
They would stand up to us.
Shocked, I introduced myself."
So, negative implication one.
Negative implication two.

When she's at the
table, men attack.

And this one is based on Trump's
very style of negotiating.

He says, "My style
of deal-making

is quite simple and
straightforward.

I aim very high, and then I
just keep pushing and pushing
to get what I'm after."

And so she cites this, a recent
study by [? Juan ?] [? and ?]

[? Lowe, ?] two behavioral
economists who found that,

"Trump, with his hyper-masculine
negotiation style serves
as a role model for men--

post-election, negotiated
agreements were more elusive,

and the primary reason was
men acting more aggressively
toward women."
So that's the bad news.

The positive implication
is, "Nevertheless, she

is demanding a
place at the table."

And here, she is
actually deviating

for from her
article for a moment
and drawing on the recent--

I don't know if you saw this
piece in The New York Times

by, Tina brown,
What Happens When
Women Stop Leading Like Men.
So she has some quotes here.

So looking at some of these
recent images of women

demanding their
place at the table.

And we see, and I
quote from the article,

"A year ago, prime Minister
Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand

was famous for being
a world leader who
gave birth while in office.

Then came the slaughter in
the Christchurch mosques,

and overnight the
gravitas in her angular

face beneath the hijab
became an iconic image
of global humanity."

What we have in
our own country--

"Among 42 new women
sworn into Congress,

young rock stars like Alexandria
Ocasio-Cortez electrify all

of us with their
passion and verve."
"But it's Nancy Pelosi--

mother of five,
grandmother of nine--

who knows how to make the
tangerine toddler in the White
House eat his spinach.

It's salutatory to
watch her corral

her rebellious democratic
brood with committee treats
and pacifying timeouts."

So those are the
three implications

that she sees for women
negotiation in the Trump era.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
